story_headline: Devos: I personally think the Department of Education should not exist
story_copy: Former Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos said she personally believes the Department of Education should not exist. DeVos made the comment during the inaugural Moms for Liberty summit in Florida over the weekend.Moms for Liberty¬†is a conservative nonprofit founded in Florida that¬†advocates for parents to have more influence over public school decisions. The organization first received national attention when it fought against mask mandates in schools and later when it opposed curriculum related to LGBTQ rights, race and discrimination.‚ÄúThere are a lot of really nice and well-meaning people there,‚Äù DeVos voiced. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mean to disparage them in any way, but they are definitely oriented around being in their roles for probably most of their careers, if not all of them.‚Äù‚Ä¶ says the guy who needlessly kept schools closed for nearly two years, because the union bosses made him.Putting parents in charge of education decisions wouldn't "destroy" public education. It would protect students from politicians like you. https://t.co/rkb2I8EHng‚Äî Betsy DeVos (@BetsyDeVos) July 18, 2022The former Trump administration official has previously said she had to work around most of the career staff at the agency in order to advance any creative reforms. During an event organized by the American Institute Enterprise last month, DeVos described dealing with an agency full of career bureaucrats.‚ÄúReally for any of the creative reforms that we advanced we really had to essentially work around most of the career staff,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBecause there were very few who would actually get the work done that needed to be done or would present options that weren‚Äôt even close to what we were attempting to do.‚ÄùFormer Secretary of Education @BetsyDeVos tells me she had a plan to ABOLISH the Department of Education and return the power to parents, but Congress wasn't interested: "Bottom line, there was no action taken. But there IS a way to shut down the Department." pic.twitter.com/ncXhAovBHT‚Äî Glenn Beck (@glennbeck) June 23, 2022She claimed that many of the staff inside the department ‚Äúdon‚Äôt have insight‚Äù into how other countries around the world deal with education. During her tenure, DeVos controversially worked to reduce her department‚Äôs authority over schools. She introduced cuts to federal education spending¬†and¬†rolling back federal guidelines¬†in favor of letting states and local districts decide their own policy.Her comments come after Rep. Thomas Massie (R-Ky.) introduced a bill to abolish the agency back in 2021.
image_caption: WASHINGTON, DC ‚Äì MARCH 28: U.S. Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos testifies during a Senate Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies Subcommittee discussing proposed budget estimates and justification for FY2020 for the Education Department on March 28, 2019 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Zach Gibson/Getty Images)

story_headline: Fla. First Lady appears to take aim at Calif. Gov. Newsom
story_copy: Fla. First Lady appears to take aim at Calif. Gov. NewsomFILE ‚Äì Florida first lady Casey DeSantis delivers remarks during the Project Opioid conference at First Presbyterian Church, in Orlando, Fla., Tuesday, Aug. 20, 2019. (Joe Burbank/Orlando Sentinel via AP, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:40 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 18, 2022Florida‚Äôs First Lady Casey DeSantis appeared to take aim at California Governor Gavin Newsom (D). DeSantis took to twitter on Monday to remind Americans her husband stood up and fought for Special Olympians who would of been sidelined if a vaccine mandate had been enforced.‚ÄúFor those who need a reminder, this is why we fight,‚Äù the first lady voiced. ‚ÄúIsabella competed in the Special Olympics because Ron DeSantis stood up and fought for her and all the other Special Olympians who would have been sidelined. We will never stop fighting for people like Isabella.‚ÄùFor those who need a reminder‚Ä¶ this is why we fight.Isabella competed in the Special Olympics because @RonDeSantisFL stood up and fought for her and all the other Special Olympians who would have been sidelined.We will never stop fighting for people like Isabella. pic.twitter.com/NARnZdSvaU‚Äî Casey DeSantis (@CaseyDeSantis) July 18, 2022This comes after Newsom insinuated Friday that Gov. Ron DeSantis (R-Fla.) threatened the Special Olympics when he informed them that they would be fined for violating state law if they enforced a mandate. Neswom claimed this motivated him to air ads in Florida attacking DeSantis.‚ÄúHe did something that tipped me very directly and that was going after the Special Olympics,‚Äù Newsom said. ‚ÄúI had an emotional response to that. That led to the consideration of doing something a little bit more expressive and that was the determination on the ad.‚ÄùIn the ad that launched in early July, Newsom said ‚Äúfreedom is under attack in Florida.‚Äù He urged Floridians to flee the Sunshine State and instead join him in California where he promises ‚Äúfreedom.‚ÄùWe‚Äôre about to celebrate Independence Day ‚Äî but Freedom¬†is under attack by Republican leaders in states like Florida.Banning books.Restricting speech.Making it harder to vote.Criminalizing women and doctors.¬†It‚Äôs time to stand up. Don‚Äôt let them take your¬†freedom. pic.twitter.com/cFI5UzgZzX‚Äî Gavin Newsom (@GavinNewsom) July 3, 2022This as DeSantis called out Newsom over California‚Äôs Covid-19 mandate for school children.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Florida first lady Casey DeSantis delivers remarks during the Project Opioid conference at First Presbyterian Church, in Orlando, Fla., Tuesday, Aug. 20, 2019. (Joe Burbank/Orlando Sentinel via AP, File)

story_headline: Good Samaritan who stopped Ind. mall shooting identified
story_copy: Good Samaritan who stopped Ind. mall shooting identifiedA customer checks a door on the closed Greenwood Park Mall in Greenwood, Ind., Monday, July 18, 2022. (AP Photo/Michael Conroy)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 3:49 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 18, 2022Police identified those involved in the mall shooting in Greenwood, Indiana. During a press conference Monday, officers released the names of the three victims who were shot and killed Sunday night.#BREAKING UPDATE: Greenwood Mayor Meyers: 3 dead, 3 injured, following shooting at Greenwood Park Mall in Indiana. Shooter was killed by armed bystander, likely preventing a further tragedy.-Shooting happened in food court.-FBI headed to scene.  pic.twitter.com/XdqAnMYkr4‚Äî Moshe Schwartz (@YWNReporter) July 18, 2022A husband and wife, Pedro Pineda and Rosa Mirian Rivera de Pineda were 56 and 37 respectively. The third victim was a 30-year-old named Victor Gomez. The gunman was reportedly 20-years-old. He was stopped by a good Samaritan who has now been identified as 22-year-old Elisjsha Dicken who is cooperating fully with authorities. The gunman opened fire in the food court which sent shoppers running for their lives.‚ÄúSo we were in the food court and we heard loud gun shots,‚Äù said witness Heather Arthur.Chris Roy, assistant manager of the mall‚Äôs Van‚Äôs shoe store was working Sunday when he saw people running through the hallway away from the food court just before closing.‚ÄúI jumped over the counter, locked the door, gathered my associates and other managers at the back door,‚Äù stated Roy.Through the back door they huddled in an interior hallway with about 40 or 50 other people, mostly customers from other stores, he claimed. That hallway didn‚Äôt have an exterior exit so they waited for police to come clear them.‚ÄúWe just instructed everybody to keep quiet,‚Äù he voiced.pic.twitter.com/r3eCthiHBD‚Äî Gregg Doyel (@GreggDoyelStar) July 17, 2022Two people were injured, including a 12-year-old girl. Both of the injured victims are hospitalized in stable condition. The shooter was shot and killed by Dicken. Authorities described him as ‚Äúa good Samaritan with a handgun.‚Äù Dicken was able to neutralize the gunman within two minutes after the gunman had already fired 24 rounds from his rifle. Dicken fired 10 shots from his Glock handgun.‚ÄúHis actions were nothing short of heroic,‚Äù voiced Greenwood Police Chief Jason Ison. ‚ÄúHe engaged the gunman from quite a distance with a handgun. He was very proficient in that, very tactically sound and as he moved to close in on the suspect he was also motioning for people to exit behind him. Many more people would have died last night if not for a responsible armed citizen that took action very quickly within the first two minutes of the shooting.‚ÄùFirst responders assisted the injured and law enforcement worked to secure the scene. Greenwood Mayor Mark W. Myers also thanked the Dicken‚Äôs for his heroism. He also said the tragedy hits the core of the community and he encouraged residents to pray for the victims and first responders.Greenwood Mayor Mark Myers says 3 shot and 3 dead including the shooter. Adds shooter was killed by ‚Äúan armed individual.‚Äù pic.twitter.com/XQicTONvIr‚Äî Angela Ganote (@angelaganote) July 18, 2022Police said to their knowledge Dicken has no military or police training. There have been more than 350 mass shootings this year, according to¬†Gun Violence Archive.
image_caption: A customer checks a door on the closed Greenwood Park Mall in Greenwood, Ind., Monday, July 18, 2022. (AP Photo/Michael Conroy)

story_headline: 4 dead after two planes collide in Las Vegas
story_copy: 4 dead after two planes collide in Las VegasOfficials investigate the wreckage of a plane at the site of a fatal crash at the North Las Vegas Airport, Sunday, July 17, 2022, in North Las Vegas, Nev. (AP Photo/John Locher)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:24 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 18, 2022Authorities confirmed there are no survivors following a plane crash in Las Vegas. Two single engine planes collided with each other Sunday afternoon, over the North Las Vegas Airport. Officials said one of the planes was preparing to land when the other hit it. Two people were aboard each plane and all four died in the incident.The airport is located just north of downtown Las Vegas and is mainly used by smaller aircraft. A local pilot said there has been concerns raised over the frequent traffic at the airport.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of traffic, so it‚Äôs always a concern about how well the airport system and flights are managed coming in and out of the airport,‚Äù said Dore Rodine, a pilot who has a plane hangared at North Las Vegas Airport.Incident Alert- at aprox 12pm today NLVFD and LVFR crews responded to a report of a mid air collision at the North Las Vegas airport. At this time there are 4 reported fatalities. Accident is still under investigation. pic.twitter.com/HhyeCDLrnE‚Äî CNLV Fire Department (@NLVFireDept) July 17, 2022Still, Rodine said this crash took him by surprise given the airport‚Äôs features.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very wide open,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs not a lot of buildings or structures in this area and with an active control tower at the time that it occurred, I‚Äôm really surprised that there wasn‚Äôt better terrain awareness. Either by one of the pilots or by the control tower.‚ÄùThe administration categorized the collision as an accident. Meanwhile, the identities of the four people killed in the crash have yet to be released.
image_caption: Officials investigate the wreckage of a plane at the site of a fatal crash at the North Las Vegas Airport, Sunday, July 17, 2022, in North Las Vegas, Nev. (AP Photo/John Locher)

story_headline: Penalty trial for Parkland shooter begins
story_copy: Penalty trial for Parkland shooter beginsFILE ‚Äì Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooter Nikolas Cruz is shown at the defense table during jury selection in the penalty phase of his trial at the Broward County Courthouse in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Tuesday, June 28, 2022. (Amy Beth Bennett/South Florida Sun-Sentinel via AP, Pool, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 5:58 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 18, 2022The penalty trial for the Parkland shooter is underway. A panel of 22 people, 12 jurors and 10 alternates were sworn in on Monday. The trial is expected to last months, but will ultimately determine the fate of the man who pleaded guilty to 17 counts of first degree murder in the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. Nikolas Cruz took the lives of 14 students, a teacher, a coach and an athletic director at the high school on Feb. 14, 2018.Opening statements reportedly took up the majority of Monday‚Äôs hearing. The defense let prosecutors have their say and have their way. Assistant Public Defender Melisa McNeill chose to reserve the team‚Äôs opening statement until the prosecution is finished presenting its case. Prosecutor Mike Satz called seven witnesses to the stand. The defense did not ask a single question of any of them.‚ÄúWe were sitting ducks,‚Äù said said Danielle Gilbert, who recorded the first series of cellphone videos shown to the jury. ‚ÄúThere was no way to protect ourselves.‚Äù Gilbert was a junior at Stoneman Douglas at the time. The videos showed students and a teacher hiding in fear as about two dozen gunshots were fired nearby. Although her body is not seen until the final video clip, victim Carmen Schentrup was already dead just a few yards away from Gilbert.HORRIFIC!   You can hear the endless gunshots from #NikolasCruz and he's killing students.  Danielle Gilbert recorded him on her cellphone. The gallery can hear but not see the video. The jury IS seeing the video.  Gilbert cries on the stand.  Family members run out of court. pic.twitter.com/rGDWzgI4S0‚Äî Cathy Russon (@cathyrusson) July 18, 2022When jurors heard those shots, the gunman at the defense table lowered his head and did not look up. Family members of his victims leaned on each other for support. Some couldn‚Äôt take it and left the room. Another could not wait five seconds into a video clip before declaring she‚Äôd had enough.‚ÄúShut it off!‚Äù called out a family member of a victim.Satz claimed that Cruz had planned to be a school shooter for a long time. He described a video that Cruz made three days before the killing where he bragged that he was going to be the ‚Äúnext school shooter‚Äù and that he hoped to kill at least 20.Prosecutors replayed the horrific day and detailed the shooter‚Äôs methodical plan. They said he was ‚Äúcold, calculated and deadly.‚Äù
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooter Nikolas Cruz is shown at the defense table during jury selection in the penalty phase of his trial at the Broward County Courthouse in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Tuesday, June 28, 2022. (Amy Beth Bennett/South Florida Sun-Sentinel via AP, Pool, File)
more_news: ¬†One-On-One With Turning Point USA‚Äôs Youngest Ambassador, Kellyanna BrookingTOPICS:FloridaMarjory Stoneman Douglas High Schoolmass shootingnewsNikolas CruzOANOANNParklandschool shooting SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: Dr. Birx claims much of her Covid guidance was arbitrary
story_copy: Dr. Birx claims much of her Covid guidance was arbitraryOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:00 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 18, 2022Dr. Deborah Birx. Jonathan Ernst/Reuters¬†Former White House COVID Response Coordinator Doctor Deborah Birx came clean about the guidance she gave to slow the spread. On Sunday, The Post Millennial reported on Birx‚Äôs testimony before Congress and her new book ‚ÄúSilent Invasion.‚ÄùShe admitted in both that the CDC data didn‚Äôt help her make clear public health recommendations. Birx‚Äôs plan that was two weeks long to slow the spread was apparently based on statistics from other countries not the US. The existing CDC data wasn‚Äôt of any use, Birx said. She picked apart the CDC‚Äôs approach and voiced that they should have been more forceful in their data collection and in going to states and demanding information.‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt do anything that would reveal my true intention,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúTo use the travel ban as one brick in the construction of a larger wall of protective measures we needed to enact very soon. Trump‚Äôs team was more concerned about the impacts and potential for loss of lives to Americans of shutting society down. She blasts the administration for their concerns over the economy, concerns which have played out in real time to the point where the country could be facing devastating impacts, as is the globe.Before posting my final review of D. Birx's book, I offer you one more excerpt on how she doctored the weekly Covid reports to the states coming from the White House. You won't believe this one. pic.twitter.com/saYjSzPhpc‚Äî Jeffrey A Tucker (@jeffreyatucker) July 16, 2022Birx urged solutions to the problem of data collection. She said that ‚Äúthere remains a lack of emphasis on active testing and there is still no sense of urgency to find the silent community invasion that occurs days to weeks before symptoms.‚Äù Birx lamented that looking back they were not more stern in their approach to guidance. She explained that it is concerning that people would not ‚Äúprioritize the health of others over their own personal liberty‚Äù and noted that early data from Europe showed widespread compliance.‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù she admitted. ‚ÄúAll I know is there was evidence from the global pandemic that natural reinfection was occurring. Since the vaccine was based on natural immunity you cannot make the conclusion that the vaccine will do better than natural infection, although it can often do slightly better.‚ÄùShe said the US had a ‚Äúsilent spread‚Äù and there was no way to track it. The doctor claimed this is what led to continuing lockdowns for over a year.
more_news: ¬†Health Officials Worldwide Growing Concerned With MonkeypoxTOPICS:CDCCOVIDdataDeborah BirxdoctornewsOANOANNPresident Trumpvaccine SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: Health officials worldwide growing concerned with Monkeypox
story_copy: Health officials worldwide growing concerned with MonkeypoxThis 1997 image provided by the CDC during an investigation into an outbreak of monkeypox, which took place in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), formerly Zaire, and depicts the dorsal surfaces of the hands of a monkeypox case patient, who was displaying the appearance of the characteristic rash during its recuperative stage. (CDC via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:00 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 18, 2022Officials at all levels of government are growing more worried about the spread of Monkeypox. Democrat lawmakers, Big Pharma and the World Health Organization are coming together to sound the alarm on the viral disease. Taking to the corporate airwaves Sunday, Washington D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser said Monkeypox cases are increasing in the capital and the city needs at least 100,000 vaccine doses to respond to the current surge which can cause a potential spike in the future.LIVE: Mayor Bowser Provides Update on Monkeypox Outbreak and Response Efforts https://t.co/1PVKf2vUz0‚Äî Mayor Muriel Bowser (@MayorBowser) July 18, 2022This comes as Manhattan Borough President Mark Levine recently took to Twitter and urged the federal government to send the Big Apple more vaccines. He revealed that New York City has 30 percent of all Monkeypox cases in the US, while having a disproportionately low number of the government‚Äôs vaccine supply. For her part, Mayor Bowser claimed that cities with robust testing resources will see more cases confirmed.‚ÄúWe need more doses and we know that work is being done,‚Äù said Bowser. ‚ÄúWe already have a very robust testing regime and we‚Äôve modeled it on what we‚Äôre able to do with COVID. We‚Äôre going to continue to test and I think because of that robust testing we‚Äôre going to see more cases.‚ÄùThe window for containing the spread of monkeypox in NYC is closing fast. Cases have more than doubled in the past week.In a bad case of deja vu we are again confronting shortages of testing, treatment & vaccine.Here‚Äôs our plan for aggressive action to meet this challenge. üßµ pic.twitter.com/afZ1DKzIFL‚Äî Mark D. Levine (@MarkLevineNYC) July 18, 2022However, former FDA chief under President Trump and coincidentally now a Pfizer executive Scott Gottlieb has a more dire assessment of the latest virus. Gottlieb warned that the Biden administration has failed to contain Monkeypox and would categorize the virus‚Äôs spread as a pandemic. He further lamented that the Biden administration will likely be reluctant to own up to its mistakes and it‚Äôs downplaying the spread.‚ÄúI think they‚Äôre going to be reluctant to use the word pandemic because it complies that they‚Äôve failed to contain this,‚Äù Gottlieb stated. ‚ÄúI think at this point we‚Äôve failed to contain this. We‚Äôre now at the cusp of this becoming an endemic virus where this now becomes something that is persistent that we need to continue to deal with. I think that the window for getting control of this and containing this probably has closed and if it hasn‚Äôt closed it‚Äôs certainly starting to close. 11,000 cases across the world right now. 1,800 cases in the US and we‚Äôre probably just detecting a fraction of the actual cases.‚ÄùThe pharma executive went on to say that there is only one FDA approved vaccine for Monkeypox and the federal government has to now go through the complicated inspection, approval and distribution processes at the same time. Gottlieb did commend the Biden administration for taking responsibility for the response from the CDC, but he argued that the White House should not have to take control of medical emergencies when there are institutions designed to handle those. He added that this is exactly what happened with the Covid-19 pandemic when President Trump was forced to take action amid a timid response by the medical establishment.‚ÄúThe white house has intervened to take more control of the response away from CDC,‚Äù the doctor voiced. ‚ÄúThis can‚Äôt be our response every time that the CDC drops the ball. The White House and political leadership needs to step in. That‚Äôs what happened here. It happened in COVID.‚ÄùSince May, DC has reported 122 #Monkeypox cases. In response, we've:‚úÖAdministered 2600+ vaccines & continue to book appointments for eligible residents‚úÖUsed contact tracing to identify 450+ close contacts‚úÖAcquired TPOXX, an antiviral treatment for use by healthcare partners‚Äî Mayor Muriel Bowser (@MayorBowser) July 18, 2022Meanwhile, the WHO is debating whether to call the Monkeypox spread a global health emergency. The body recently updated the public on the nearly 10,000 cases confirmed over the past few months. It also recently reported Monkeypox cases tripled across Europe which made health officials in neighboring regions concerned about a potential massive surge. WHO officials worried that the number of confirmed cases may not account for the real number of cases.‚ÄúTesting remains a challenge and it‚Äôs highly probable that there are a significant number of cases not being picked up,‚Äù expressed WHO officials. ‚ÄúEurope is the current epicenter of the outbreak, recording more than 80 percent of cases globally.‚ÄùIn the meantime, a WHO emergency committee is expected to meet on Thursday to assess the threat of Monkeypox. Additionally, doctor Gottlieb claimed there won‚Äôt be an explosion of cases that come in the future. He pointed to the slow progression from contraction to showing symptoms.Gottlieb also said lawmakers in Washington D.C. desperately need to reform its emergency response tactics. He said if those protocols remain the same then the US will be behind whenever a new pandemic hits US shores.
image_caption: This 1997 image provided by the CDC during an investigation into an outbreak of monkeypox, which took place in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), formerly Zaire, and depicts the dorsal surfaces of the hands of a monkeypox case patient, who was displaying the appearance of the characteristic rash during its recuperative stage. (CDC via AP)

story_headline: Poll: Voters favor GOP over Dems for Congress
story_copy: Poll: Voters favor GOP over Dems for CongressA woman votes in the presidential primary election at the the Summit View Church of the Nazarene in Kansas City, Mo., on March 10, 2020.Charlie Riedel / AP fileOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 10:44 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 18, 2022Americans appear to favor Republicans over Democrats for Congress ahead of the upcoming midterm elections. That‚Äôs according to a new poll released Sunday that surveyed over 1,000 registered voters. According to the data, 44 percent would vote for a generic GOP candidate compared to 41 percent who would back a Democrat.Forty-one percent of participants were Democrats, 41 percent were Republican and 19 percent were independent. Some analysts predict Republicans have a strong chance to take the majority of the body due to Democrats focusing on cultural and social issues, instead of economic issues.Meanwhile, Sen. Rick Scott (R-Fla.) said voters are focusing on avoiding an economic catastrophe and not on who will be president in 2024. During an interview Sunday, the Republican stressed the November election will be a referendum on President Joe Biden and the Democrat Party‚Äôs failed policies over the past two years..@JoeBiden‚Äôs reckless spending & raging inflation are pushing our nation & American families to the breaking point.Build Back Better? No. Biden is charting a path to bankruptcy. pic.twitter.com/rhbIV1LFei‚Äî Rick Scott (@SenRickScott) July 7, 2022Scott added, Americans care about what immediately affects them, including skyrocketing inflation, woke school curriculums and consequences of defund the police rhetoric. He pointed out Democrats are on the wrong side of those issues. The Florida lawmaker then blasted Democrats for being ‚Äúdo-nothing people‚Äù who just want to raise taxes, so they can spend taxpayers‚Äô money.‚ÄúMy proposal is do what I did as governor, get everybody back to work,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúWhen I was governor I added 1.7 million jobs. That‚Äôs how you get everybody to have skin in the game. But the Democrats, they want to spend your money.‚ÄùScott went on to stress, Americans are feeling the pain of Democrat failed policies, adding that will likely lead to a ‚Äúbloodbath‚Äù for Democrats in the midterm elections.
image_caption: A woman votes in the presidential primary election at the the Summit View Church of the Nazarene in Kansas City, Mo., on March 10, 2020.Charlie Riedel / AP file

story_headline: Wis. Speaker Vos says state may re-do 2020 election if fraud is proven in court
story_copy: Wis. Speaker Vos says state may re-do 2020 election if fraud is proven in courtFILE ‚Äì Wisconsin Assembly Speaker Robin Vos talks to the media in the Assembly chambers during the governor‚Äôs State of the State speech at the state Capitol Tuesday, Feb. 15, 2022, in Madison, Wis. (AP Photo/Andy Manis)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:27 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 18, 2022Wisconsin State Assembly Speaker Robin Vos said the state may have to re-do the 2020 presidential election. While speaking at a Wisconsin GOP press conference, he explained it is generally not possible to overturn results of an election.However, Vos then noted if evidence of 2020 election fraud in the state if proven in courts then the State Assembly will have to act and likely hold a new election. His remarks came after the Wisconsin Supreme Court outlawed ballot dropboxes and ruled they can only be installed inside polling stations.Vos is now expected to provide courts with election probe records by former State Supreme Court Justice Michael Gableman. Former President Donald Trump recently criticized Vos for taking too long to challenge 2020 fraud and for being indecisive about ongoing election litigation.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Wisconsin Assembly Speaker Robin Vos talks to the media in the Assembly chambers during the governor‚Äôs State of the State speech at the state Capitol Tuesday, Feb. 15, 2022, in Madison, Wis. (AP Photo/Andy Manis)
more_news: ¬†Ariz. Gov. Ducey Slams Biden Over Saudi Trip, Says President Must Increase US Oil ProductionTOPICS:2020 electionDonald TrumpelectionJoe BidenMichael GablemannewsOANOANNpoltiicsrobin vosvotingsWisconsin SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: Biden staff rushes to his defense amid outcry over Saudi trip
story_copy: Biden staff rushes to his defense amid outcry over Saudi tripFILE ‚Äì Pentagon spokesman John Kirby speaks during a briefing at the Pentagon in Washington, Wednesday, March 9, 2022. (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:28 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 19, 2022President Joe Biden‚Äôs national security staff is rushing to his defense amid outcry over his recent trip to Saudi Arabia. During an interview Monday, White House spokesman John Kirby stressed the US and Saudi Arabia are deeply entangled. The Coordinator for Strategic Communications added, the Biden administration has enormous interest in the kingdom and could not pass up a meeting with the Crown Prince.His comments comes as critics have lambasted Biden for begging Saudi Arabia for oil and being friendly with its leadership, despite calling it a ‚Äúpariah state‚Äù on the campaign trail. However, Kirby claimed Biden‚Äôs Middle East tour was integral in advancing his agenda and asserted it will yield some positive results.‚ÄúThey (the meetings) produced results and they will probably produce results in the future that are in the best interest of the American people,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúThe President went on this trip because it was in the national interest that he do it.‚ÄùThe White House aid went on to say Biden and the Crown Prince came together on several issues, including efforts to denuclearize Iran. Meanwhile, White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre faced tough questions about Biden‚Äôs trip to the Middle East and his talks with Saudi leadership.During a press briefing Monday, she defended Biden while echoing his claims that he was tough to those he spoke to and discussed human rights with them. Her remarks came despite the foreign minister and Saudi leadership denying Biden had any such conversation with them."Does the president still believe that Saudi Arabia and the crown prince should be considered 'a pariah'?"KARINE JEAN-PIERRE: *word salad* pic.twitter.com/tI8cYj4G0c‚Äî RNC Research (@RNCResearch) July 18, 2022Jean-Pierre was asked if Biden still labels Saudi Arabi as a ‚Äúpariah‚Äù despite the meeting, but played off the question by saying Biden has already addressed it. The President has not been clear with Saudi Arabia‚Äôs status, only saying he doesn‚Äôt regret labeling them a ‚Äúpariah‚Äù during the campaign.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Pentagon spokesman John Kirby speaks during a briefing at the Pentagon in Washington, Wednesday, March 9, 2022. (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta, File)

story_headline: White House touts slight decline in gas prices, denies possible recession
story_copy: White House touts slight decline in gas prices, denies possible recessionCouncil of Economic Advisers member Jared Bernstein speaks at a press briefing at the White House in Washington, Monday, July 18, 2022. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:39 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 19, 2022President Joe Biden‚Äôs economy czar, Jared Bernstein, appeared to admit inflation wasn‚Äôt transitory, while still asking the country to trust its policies moving forward.¬†On Monday, Bernstein held a press conference to showcase the 34th day of declining fuel costs. He touted the price of gas has dropped 50 cents per gallon since its June peak and reassured the public the trend should continue so long as circumstances remain favorable.‚ÄúWe think it‚Äôs reasonable to expect more gas stations to lower their prices in response to lower input costs and thus, barring unforeseen market disruptions to see average prices fall below $4 per gallon in more places in coming weeks,‚Äù stated the economic adviser.However, the press raised concerns about Bernstein‚Äôs forecast as officials have promised inflation was transitory, only for rates to continue hovering at 40-year highs. The adviser downplayed such worries, trumpeting a number of factors to bolster his claim that the Biden economy is robust.‚ÄúSo I think if you look at the strength of the current economy, if you look at the strength of the labor market, if you look at the strength of consumer spending, you would conclude that where we are right now remains solidly within expansion,‚Äù he claimed. ‚ÄúI think we can confidently say that these numbers that we‚Äôre posting are very much inconsistent with a recessionary call given where we are right now.‚ÄùHowever, members of the press refused to relent pointing to Biden‚Äôs refusal to take credit for any of the economic woes that have taken place during his presidency. Bernstein shot back by disagreeing with their assessment and praising Biden‚Äôs policies.‚ÄúI think what‚Äôs happening here is a President who is working tirelessly to address the largest constraint, probably the toughest constraint facing American households right now: the the budgetary impacts of these elevated prices,‚Äù stated the economy czar. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre showing you here today some real results.‚ÄùÔªøThe price of gasoline remains more than $2 higher per gallon than when Biden first took office. Although the President has often blamed Russia for the pain at the pump, prices had already risen a dollar per gallon prior to the invasion of Ukraine.A March study by the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank found found half of the inflation rate in quarter four of last year had been triggered by bloated pandemic spending packages. Nonetheless, the Biden administration seems to be telling Americans to be grateful for a slight decline in gas prices as the population continues to feel pain in their pockets.
image_caption: Council of Economic Advisers member Jared Bernstein speaks at a press briefing at the White House in Washington, Monday, July 18, 2022. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)

story_headline: Fauci: Not going to retire, may step down from current role
story_copy: Fauci: Not going to retire, may step down from current roleFILE ‚Äì Dr. Anthony Fauci, Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, holds his face mask in his hands as he attends a House Committee on Appropriations subcommittee hearing on about the budget request for the National Institutes of Health, May 11, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:21 PM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 19, 2022National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) Director and Chief White House Medical Advisor, Dr. Anthony Fauci said he‚Äôs not going anywhere. While speaking at an event hosted by The Hill Tuesday, Fauci dismissed a recent Politico report claiming he was going to retire by the end of President Joe Biden‚Äôs term.However, Dr. Fauci said he does not see himself staying in his current position, regardless of who is occupying the White House next. He also said he can still contribute to medical research at the federal level. His comments come as the nation‚Äôs highest paid unelected bureaucrat¬† has come under immense scrutiny over the past few years for his positions on vaccine and mask mandates as well as funding gain-of-function research at the Wuhan lab in China.Dr. Fauci is currently 81-years-old and has been working for the federal government for over 50 years. He has been at the NIAID since 1984 and has spent the majority of his career studying HIV, Ebola and other highly infections diseases. In 2020, Fauci became the face of the government‚Äôs response to the COVID-19 pandemic, where he advocated universal masking, economic lockdowns and mandatory vaccinations.Meanwhile, government watchdog Judicial Watch is taking legal action against the Biden administration while seeking the records of NIH official Christine Grady, who is the wife of Dr. Fauci. In the Freedom of Information Act lawsuit, Judicial Watch requests a court order the Department of Health and Human Services to produce Grady‚Äôs financial disclosure documents and other information.BREAKING: Judicial Watch filed a FOIA lawsuit on behalf of American Transparency (https://t.co/h4AxlvT1ZF) against HHS for employment and financial disclosure records for the NIH chief of the Clinical Center‚Äôs Department of Bioethics,Christine Grady. READ: https://t.co/fv7JoeCk6D pic.twitter.com/UxeNN82FhP‚Äî Judicial Watch ‚öñÔ∏è (@JudicialWatch) July 18, 2022Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton said the group has good reason to believe the documents will give Americans a fuller picture of Dr. Fauci‚Äôs conflicts of interest. The conservative watchdog has also filed two other suits seeking information from the Department of Health and Human Services and Dr. Fauci himself.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Dr. Anthony Fauci, Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, holds his face mask in his hands as he attends a House Committee on Appropriations subcommittee hearing on about the budget request for the National Institutes of Health, May 11, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin, File)

story_headline: Prosecutors drop murder charges against NYC Bodega worker
story_copy: Prosecutors drop murder charges against NYC Bodega workerOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:56 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 19, 2022Prosecutors are moving to drop murder charges against a New York City bodega worker who fatally stabbed a man who attacked him. The Manhattan district attorney filed a motion to dismiss the charges against 61-year-old Jose Alba Tuesday.This came after a reported probe determined they could not prove Alba was not justified in using deadly force. Alba contends he acted in self-defense when he killed 34-year Simon Austin, who camera footage shows attacked him behind the counter of the Blue Moon bodega on July 1.61-year-old bodega worker Jose Alba was attacked by an enraged career criminal, Austin Simon, who went behind the counter and choked him over a bag of chips. Alba defended himself, and Simon died. DA Alvin Bragg has charged him with murder. pic.twitter.com/FIfL1O1q7X‚Äî Ian Miles Cheong (@stillgray) July 7, 2022The case drew widespread scrutiny with Mayor Eric Adams among several of Albas notable supporters. Adams said he cannot dictate or mandate how the Manhattan district attorney prosecutes crimes. However, the Mayor did add that his heart goes out to the hard-working and honest Alba.‚ÄúI am hoping that we take all of that into consideration as this hard-working New Yorker was doing his job and someone aggressively went behind the counter to attack him,‚Äù Adams stated. ‚ÄúI support hard-working, innocent people that are doing their job.‚ÄùThe United Bodegas of America and Yemeni American Merchants Association has been lobbying for Albas‚Äô charges to be dropped, while explaining his act of self-defense was justified.

story_headline: Navy selects first female Blue Angels jet pilot
story_copy: Navy selects first female Blue Angels jet pilotOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:58 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 19, 2022The US Navy named its first female jet pilot for the Blue Angels. On Monday, the Navy selected Lt. Amanda Lee for the 2023 show season. Lee, who is assigned to the Gladiators of Strike Fighter Squadron 106, worked her way up from an aviation electronics tech in 2007. She will undergo a five-month training this fall before officially becoming one of the Blue Angels‚Äô Super Hornet pilots.In this photo released by Defense Visual Information Distribution Service, Lt. Amanda Lee is shown. The U.S. Navy‚Äôs Blue Angels flying squadron have named a woman as a demonstration pilot for the first time. Lt. Amanda Lee, of Mounds View, Minnesota, was announced Monday, July 18, 2022, as a pilot assigned to the the ‚ÄúGladiators‚Äù of Strike Fighter Squadron 106. (CPO Paul Archer/DVIDS U.S. Navy via AP)¬†While Lee is the first female that will fly a Blue Angels fighter jet, there have been previous females who have contributed to the team in other ways. That‚Äôs according to a Navy press release. For instance, Marine Maj. Katie Cook was the first female pilot in general. She commented on Lee‚Äôs accomplishment saying, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a long legacy of women, first in naval aviation before us, and so we would never even have this opportunity without them.‚ÄùBlue Angels training is set to be begin in September and the new season is set to kick-off in March. According to reports, there are 33 airshows scheduled so far, including locations in both the US and Canada.
image_caption: In this photo released by Defense Visual Information Distribution Service, Lt. Amanda Lee is shown. The U.S. Navy‚Äôs Blue Angels flying squadron have named a woman as a demonstration pilot for the first time. Lt. Amanda Lee, of Mounds View, Minnesota, was announced Monday, July 18, 2022, as a pilot assigned to the the ‚ÄúGladiators‚Äù of Strike Fighter Squadron 106. (CPO Paul Archer/DVIDS U.S. Navy via AP)

story_headline: U.K. MP Tom Tugendhat voted out of prime minister race
story_copy: U.K. MP Tom Tugendhat voted out of prime minister raceTom Tugendhat is seen at the launch of his campaign to be Conservative Party leader and Prime Minister, at 4 Millbank, London, Tuesday July 12, 2022.(Yui Mok/PA via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:18 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 19, 2022U.K. officials post the results of the third round of voting to see who will become the next prime minister. Candidate Tom Tugendhat dropped out of the race after receiving only 31 votes from his colleagues. Despite losing, Tugendhat took the results in stride and released a video statement thanking his supporters.Although it wasn‚Äôt to be today, I am immensely proud of the positive vision we put forward for our country. Thank you to all those who supported me and believed in #ACleanStart. This is only the beginning! pic.twitter.com/KgODn9xuNx‚Äî Tom Tugendhat (@TomTugendhat) July 18, 2022The remaining four candidates, who will move on to a fourth round of voting later Tuesday, were announced during a press briefing hosted by the Conservative Party‚Äôs 1922 Committee.‚ÄúI have the results of the third ballot: 357 votes were cast out of a possible total of 358,‚Äù announced¬†Sir Graham Brady, Chairman of the 1922 Committee. ‚ÄúI will, again, read the name of the candidate and the number of votes cast in alphabetical order: (Kemi) Badenoch, 58; (Penny) Mordaunt, 82; (Rishi) Sunak, 115. (Liz) Truss, 71. (Tom) Tugendhat, 31. So, Tom Tugendhat is eliminated from the election.‚ÄùThe final two candidates will be confirmed on Wednesday.

story_headline: CCP: Speaker Pelosi visiting Taiwan violates Chinese territorial integrity
story_copy: CCP: Speaker Pelosi visiting Taiwan violates Chinese territorial integrityFILE ‚Äì U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of Calif., speaks at her weekly press conference, July 14, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. China will take ‚Äúresolute and strong measures‚Äù should Pelosi proceed with reported plans for a visit to Taiwan, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday, July 19, 2022. (AP Photo/Mariam Zuhaib, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:37 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 19, 2022House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) will travel to Taiwan in August. According to reports Tuesday, the Democrat has rescheduled her visit to the country next month after cancelling an April trip following a positive COVID test.The trip announcement has, once again, angered the Chinese Communist Party who believe Taiwan is an integral part of China. According to the CCP, Pelosi‚Äôs trip to the island nation will violate this so-called One China Policy.‚ÄúIf Speaker Pelosi visits Taiwan, it will seriously violate the One China Policy and the provisions of the Three China-U.S. Joint Communiqu√©s, seriously undermine China‚Äôs sovereignty and territorial integrity, seriously impact the political foundation of China-U.S. relations, and send a seriously wrong signal to the separatist forces of Taiwan independence,‚Äù stated Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian. ‚ÄúChina is firmly opposed to this.‚Äù#China urges that #US must not arrange House Speaker Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs Taiwan visit, stop official exchange with #Taiwan, and stop creating tensions over the Taiwan Straits, or China will take forceful countermeasures: Chinese Foreign Ministry pic.twitter.com/qc4Xl0fS8H‚Äî Zhang MeifangÂº†ÁæéËä≥ (@CGMeifangZhang) July 19, 2022Pelosi‚Äôs visit to the nation will be the first by a sitting Speaker since Republican Newt Gingrich in 1997.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of Calif., speaks at her weekly press conference, July 14, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. China will take ‚Äúresolute and strong measures‚Äù should Pelosi proceed with reported plans for a visit to Taiwan, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday, July 19, 2022. (AP Photo/Mariam Zuhaib, File)
